job_title: Senior Finance Position in London, England
pros:
A strong and well respected central finance function. 

The University is involved in a vast range of activities which keeps your job interesting from a finance perspective.

All three campuses are easily accessible if you're based in mid Kent. The university also offers a free shuttle bus service if you need to travel between sites.

The University puts the student experience first in everything it does.

The University offers decent levels of pay.
cons:
There is zero work life balance which is extremely unusual for a HE institution. Working the equivalent of an additional 10-15 hours per week (for no personal benefit) was very common.

There is very little staff development opportunity. I was not offered any training other than policy/statutory training.

Very poor finance systems in place. A lot of very manual work required.

pros: None at the moment. Maybe that changes at one point, but my hopes are not high.
cons:
UoG management, starting with VC, does their utmost best to down-manage this once great institution. Their general stance is to dump more and more work on academic and admin staff, without additional compensation, whilst they authorise massive salary increases for themselves. But what do they have to show for it? UoG is going down the tables, so they should actually take a massive pay-cut and pass the savings on to staff. It is the staff, both academic and admin, that make a university work - not the managers who have frankly no idea what is going on.
Management is KPI-driven, desperate, and lacking feasible visions. I am not surprised that students do not speak highly of UoG. There is no identification with the institution - I predict that UoG will come to the brink of irrelevance once Brexit is through, and their most skilled staff would have left for greener pastures.
In a nutshell, UoG has no appreciation whatsoever for their most important assets - the staff working there!

pros: Clock in and clock out daily 9:15 to 17:00 to avoid a run in with the head of school. Zero job security, poor morale among lecturers, especially within Engineering make this a challenging place to work. Outdated programme offerings place this job on a declining spiral with ever fewer applicants for study, making a position here great for future redundancy packages.
cons: Zero appreciation by management of achievements, poor new curricula in Engineering means lower student numbers and further redundancies among an already diminished area of study. Poor morale among students.

job_title: Central Recruitment Services Assistant in London, England
pros: Excellent opportunities for students to work on and off campus for the university. The pay is fair. The working hours are flexible to give you time to study and go to lectures. Great to have students working for students. Social events with the university full time staff are also great. You get a lot of contacts while networking at these events and also it improves certain skills you need for future employability that your course may not give to you.
cons: to be honest I cant really think of anything bad.

pros: Very nice atmosphere, helpful support staff, fantastic culture and values you can really tell that equality is very important throughout the company
cons: Some of the systems in place are outdated such as the website and some of the programs, but this is understandable because it takes a lot of time and effort to replace all of these

review_title: Depends what you're here for - A few ups, many downs
pros: Very collegiate atmosphere, very social, close to the students, beautiful campi both in Greenwich and Medway. Great if all you want to do is teaching.
cons:
100% (and beyond) teaching, research is expected to be done in your own time.
Majority students lackadaisical.

pros: Greenwich is a great location with new faces of tourist everyday. Reasonable paid with work-life balance.  Staff are diversified and supportive in helping you to get things done.
cons: The university expands to 3 campus: Greenwich, Avery Hill and Medway which are not close to each other. It takes time to get to different campus. The administrative work can take longer than expected here.

review_title: You want to love UoG but it is getting harder to want to work here.
pros:
Hardworking and committed employees in the professional services.

Excellent students who want to succeed. 

Good pay levels for SE London.
cons:
Lack of senior management engagement.

Zero university wide communication. 

More committees & strategic groups than any one university could reasonably need.

pros: Nice campus, rich history. Students with interesting backgrounds
cons:
Higher management has the audacity to say that the previous year's strategic plan has been met "in spirit". This gives you an understanding of how much they care
They hire young academics with PhDs asking them to conduct research, but with ZERO internal financial support whatsoever and inhumane teaching workloads. They need to understand that research needs time and doesn't grow on trees.
They also need to be much clearer on the fact that there is no time for research and you are expected to do this on your own personal time.

job_title: IT Support Technician in Greenwich, England
pros: If you're a student you can get a lot of work done. There isn't too much responsibilities, fairly straight forward for someone who is into tech. The team is good and go out for drinks regularly. They are extremely flexible based on your availability.
cons: Not enough shifts or responsibility. Not enough room for development or any technical challenges so it can get a bit repetitive and boring.

pros: It's a good opportunity to enhance your communication, teamwork and you make new friends. The job is really fun. Also, they pay you really well like 10.77 to 11.63 ph. I liked the role and would encourage students to apply for this.
cons: Only University Of Greenwich students can apply for it. Also, no one can depend on this role for a living as there are no contract hours per week.

pros: Team was very friendly and accomodating. Flexible with work hours. Keen to let me be independent.
cons: There isn't much scope for progression with regards to role or salary, although they do tend to promote internally when a role does come up.

job_title: Ph D Candidate in London, England
pros: - The environment has been supportive and friendly with regard to any request.
cons: - Strict policies do not allow for adequate use of equipment, e.g. HPC, PC (for computer science staff). This drawback has been quite an issue for me as a Ph.D. candidate, as I couldn't perform the necessary experimental work in time.

pros: Most students and staff are really friendly and helpful
cons: Like most HE institutions it struggles with funding. However, poor management from the very top infects all levels across the University.
